bioghist.p: Father Edward Valentine Stanford (1897-1966) entered the Augustinian Order in 1917 after completing three years at Boston College. He was ordained in Philadelphia in 1922. Father Stanford’s first assignment was to Villanova College, in 1923, as teacher of Descriptive Geometry. Later, he assumed the duties of chaplain of the College. From 1932 to 1944 he served as president of Villanova College. In 1940 he was elected president of the Association of American Colleges. Noted as an administrator, he served during World War II as advisory-board member of the War Manpower Commission. In 1944 Father Stanford was appointed Prior and Rector of Augustinian College in Washington, D.C. It was during his term there that he helped organize, and acted as secretary of, the Catholic Commission for Intellectual and Cultural Affairs, a group of learned Catholic scholars. In 1950 Father Stanford moved to Archbishop Carroll High School in Washington, D.C., as the schools’ first Principal and Superior of the Augustinian Community there. He was principal there for nine years. In 1959 Father Stanford was assigned to Saint Mary’s Hall, Villanova, Pennsylvania, and was give the opportunity to devote his time to educational pursuits and writing. Father was the author of several books including A Guide to Catholic College Administration. He held honorary degrees from the University of Pennsylvania, Saint John’s University, Loyola University of Chicago, and Boston College.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of the papers of Father Edward V. Stanford. The collection consists of correspondence, legal documents, minutes, news clippings, personal papers, printed materials, programs, and reports. The largest portion of the collection is made up of correspondence, which covers a range of topics, including academic reorganization, anniversary celebrations, commencements, and Villanova's NROTC program. Of note are a number of letters to Stanford from Villanova students and alumni serving in the armed forces during and after World War II. The correspondence files also include documents related to Stanford's involvement in various University committees and outside academic associations. Legal files consist of leases for St. Mary’s Hall and St. Rita’s Hall. Minutes and agendas are present for several outside committees and organizations with which Father Stanford was involved, including the American Council on Education (1943-1951); the Catholic Committee on Intellectual and Cultural Affairs (1946-1954); the National Catholic Education Association, Eastern Regional Unit (1934-1942); and the Centennial Executive Committee (1939-1943). News media include two scrapbooks of clippings about Stanford (1931-1947) and reprints of articles by Stanford on Catholic education, military service, the intersection of war and higher education, and mixed religion marriages. Personal papers include book reviews; addresses given at Villanova and before various professional associations; draft and galley proofs for Preparing for Marriage; and honorary degrees. Printed materials include bulletins, and reports related to military training and ROTC programs. There are also miscellaneous programs for masses, convocations, and testimonial dinners. Finally, the collection includes reports of the Catholic Committee on Intellectual and Cultural Affairs; the National Catholic Educational Association; the American Council on Education; the NROTC program; and various committees and councils of the University.
